Nunes' comments came hours after the release of a formerly classified memo — which was orchestrated by Nunes — that claims a warrant to monitor communications between former Trump campaign adviser Carter Page relied heavily on a dossier compiled by former British spy Christopher Steele.

Democrats have claimed that the memo is aimed to politicize intelligence and distort facts of the Trump-Russia investigation, which is being conducted by special counsel Robert Mueller and being overseen by Rosenstein.

Rep. Devin Nunes said Friday he's happy to keep working with Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein and believes he can "fix the problems" at the Department of Justice.
The California Republican also said that the memo was phase one of their investigation and that his committee is currently investigating other departments, including the State Department.
We continue to work to find answers and asking the right questions to try to get to the bottom of what exactly the State Department was up to in terms of this Russian investigation."

"We are in the middle of what I call phase 2 of our investigation which involves other departments, specifically the State Department and the involvement they had in this."
